B44: The Sicilian Defence is a chess opening that begins with the following moves:1.e4 c5ECOB20–B99OriginGiulio Cesare Polerio, 1594Named afterSicilyParentKing's Pawn Game. Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov are two of the most famous players to have played the Sicilian. The Sicilian is the most played and most analysed opening at both the club and master levels. It fell out of favour when some of the world's leading players rejected it. The most frequent continuation is 3...Nf6 4.Be2, when 4...Nxe4? loses to 5.Qa4+ and likewise 4 ...Nc4?: loses to 6 d5 and 7a4+. 2.d3 signals White's intention to develop along King's Indian Attack lines, and usually transposes to the Closed Sicilian. White often supports the e5-pawn with 3.f4 or 3.Nf3. The drawback of 2.e5 is that no additional pressure is brought to the centre. The Sicilian Defence has more codes than any other opening. The Wing Gambit is generally considered too reckless, and rarely seen in grandmaster praxis. GM Joe Gallagher calls it "a forgotten relic, hardly having set foot in a tournament hall since ... well, not a lot"  c3 Sicilian is popular. Players usually enter the Grand Prix Attack by playing 2Nc4 before 3f3 or 3f4.
D12: The Slav Defense is one of the primary defenses to the Queen's Gambit. It was analyzed as early as 1590, but not explored extensively until the 1920s. Many masters of Slavic descent helped develop the theory of this opening, including Alapin, Alekhine and Bogoljubov. After 3...Nf6, the main line is 4.Nc3. Black can try the Winawer Countergambit, 3...e5, which was introduced in Marshall–Winawer, Monte Carlo 1901 but this is thought to be slightly better for White. White can also try the following alternatives:4.Qc2 or 4.Qb3. Another way to play is 4...Bg4. White's sharpest try against 4...dxc4 is the Slav Geller Gambit, 5.e4. With 5.a4, White acts against ...b5 and prepares 6.e 4 and 7.Bxc4. Black's main move is 5...Bf5.

The Wing Gambit is generally considered too reckless, and rarely seen in grandmaster praxis. GM Joe Gallagher calls it "a forgotten relic, hardly having set foot in a tournament hall since ... well, not a lot"  c3 Sicilian is popular. Players usually enter the Grand Prix Attack by playing 2Nc4 before 3f3 or 3f4.

D23: The Queen's Gambit Accepted is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 d52. c4 dxc4. It is the third most popular option on Black's second move, after 2...e6 and 2...c6 (the Slav Defense) Black usually allows the pawn to be recaptured and uses the time expended to play against White's centre. 3.e4 is an old move that became popular again in the 1990s. The Alekhine Variation focuses on rapid development of pieces along with domination of the centre. 3.e3 prepares immediate recovery of the pawn and has often been employed by strong players, including Anatoly Karpov. 3. Nc3 was recommended by Keene and Jacobs in their opening repertoire for White. The queen check by 3.Qa4+ Nc6 4.Nf3 will quickly regain the pawn with Qxc4. 3...e5, 3...Nf6, and 3...a6 are all reasonable replies.

D70: The Grünfeld Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g63. Nc3 d5. Black offers White the possibility of 4.cxd5, which may be followed by 4...Nxd5 and 5.e4, giving White an imposing central pawn duo. In classical opening theory this imposing pawn centre was held to give White a large advantage, but the hypermodern school, which was coming to the fore in the 1920s, held that a large pawn centre could be a liability rather than an asset. White can develop their pieces in a number of ways in the Exchange Variation. For decades, theory held that the correct method of development was with Bc4 and Ne2, often followed by 0-0 and f4–f5, playing for a central breakthrough or kingside attack. In the late 1970s, Karpov, Kasparov and others found different methods to play the Exchange Variant with White. Grünfeld Gambit (Gambit, 1998) The Grunfeld for the Attacking Player (Batsford, 2002) An Expert's Guide to the 7.Bc4 Gruenfeld (Chess Stars, 2006) Play the Grünfield (Everyman Chess, 2007)
B26: The Sicilian Defence is a chess opening that begins with the following moves:1.e4 c5ECOB20–B99OriginGiulio Cesare Polerio, 1594Named afterSicilyParentKing's Pawn Game. Grünfeld Gambit (Gambit, 1998) The Grunfeld for the Attacking Player (Batsford, 2002) An Expert's Guide to the 7.Bc4 Gruenfeld (Chess Stars, 2006) Play the Grünfield (Everyman Chess, 2007)
B19: Classical Variation: 1.e4 c6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Bf5 5. Ng3 Bg6 6. h4 h6 7. Nf3 Nd7 8. h5 Bh7 9. Bd3 Bxd3 10.Qxd3. Although White's pawn on h5 looks ready to attack, it can prove a weakness in an endgame. Viktor Korchnoi played 5...exf6 many times (including his first world championship match with Anatoly Karpov), and this line has also been employed by Ulf Andersson. The 3...Bf5 variation that follows 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 g6 has gained popularity after having been widely regarded as inferior for many years. The Panov–Botvinnik Attack begins with the move 4.c4. The Fantasy Variation aims to exploit White's weaknesses on the a7–g1 diagonal. The Two Knights Variation was played by Bobby Fischer in his youth, but has since declined in popularity. After the moves 1.e4 c6 2.Nc3 d5 3.Qf3!? (Goldman Variation), White's position is sound according to Graham Burgess. The percentage white wins, black wins or a draw occurs in the games of highly rated players (2200+ FIDE) in four lines of the Caro–Kann Defence. Other lines are ineffective or doubtful.
D83: The Grünfeld Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g63. Nc3 d5. Black offers White the possibility of 4.cxd5, which may be followed by 4...Nxd5 and 5.e4, giving White an imposing central pawn duo. In classical opening theory this imposing pawn centre was held to give White a large advantage, but the hypermodern school, which was coming to the fore in the 1920s, held that a large pawn centre could be a liability rather than an asset. White can develop their pieces in a number of ways in the Exchange Variation. For decades, theory held that the correct method of development was with Bc4 and Ne2, often followed by 0-0 and f4–f5, playing for a central breakthrough or kingside attack. In the late 1970s, Karpov, Kasparov and others found different methods to play the Exchange Variant with White. Grünfeld Gambit (Gambit, 1998) The Grunfeld for the Attacking Player (Batsford, 2002) An Expert's Guide to the 7.Bc4 Gruenfeld (Chess Stars, 2006) Play the Grünfield (Everyman Chess, 2007)
B21: The Sicilian Defence is one of the most popular openings in chess. It is used by world champions Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov. After 1.e4 c5 there are three options for Black: 2...d6, 2...Nc6, and 2...e6. The Smith-Morra Gambit is named after Pierre Morra and Ken Smith, who helped popularize the opening. Black can either castle kingside with 7.Bb3 a6 or 8.0-0 (the Fischer–Sozin Attack) Black can also try Benko's move 6...Qb6, which forces White to make a decision over the d4-knight. The critical test of Black's move order is 5.c4, the Maróczy Bind. After 1.e4 c5 2.Nf3, Black has some less commonly played options apart from 2...d6, 2...Nc6 and 2...e6. White's strongest reply is to chase the knight by 3.e5 Nd5 4.Nc3 and now (a) 4...Nxc3. Many lines transpose to the Open Sicilian, the Moscow Variation or the Rossolimo Variation. White can play the positional 5.Bb5, threatening to double Black's pawns with Bxc6. The Sicilian Defence is classified under the codes B20 through B99. White may decline the gambit with 3. nc3, called the "Toilet Variation", so named after its reputed place of invention.
D48: The Semi-Slav Defense is a variation of the Queen's Gambit Declined chess opening. It is defined by the position reached after the moves:1. d4 d52. c4 c63. Nf3 Nf64. Nc3 e6. After the move order 1.d4 d5 2.c4 c6 3.Nc3 Black has the opportunity to respond with 3...e6 instead of 3...Nf6. This "triangle setup" opens up some new alternatives for both players on the fourth move. The Meran Variation is one of the main variations of the Semi-Slav. White plays 6.Bd3, provoking the continuation 6...dxc4 7.Bxc4 b5. The line was first played in 1906 in the game Schlechter–Perlis. The variation takes its name from the town of Meran in northern Italy. 8...Bb7 was long considered virtually unplayable due to the line 9.e4 b4 10.Na4 c5 11.e5 Nd5 12.Nxc5 Nxc5 13.dxc5 Bxc5 14.Bb5+ and the black king will be stuck in the center. But after 14...Ke7 Black is completely fine and might be even better, with a very strong knight on d5 and strong bishops aiming at the White kingside. Black keeps his c-pawn on c5 is: 11...Qc7 12.dxe6 fxe6 13.Ng5 Qc6 after which there are many different ways to continue for both sides. White's strategic idea in the Meran is to push e3–e4, and with a bishop on d6 Black is always ready to meet this with e6–e5, and typically Black is doing fine after such moves. Most often White players choose the move 7.Bd3. Karpov first played 7.Be2 but it soon transpired that the d3-square gives White better chances. Play often continues 12.dxe5 Nxe5 13.Nxe5 Bxe5 14.h3 with some slight advantage for White. If Black simply takes the pawn with 7...Nxg4, White will respond with 8.Rg1. Black now has a number of playable continuations, including Qf6, Nxh2, f5, h5 and Nh6. The Moscow Variation 5...h6 6.Bxf6 Qxf6 gives rise to play of a very different character. Botvinnik Variation is probably one of the most complicated of all chess openings. The opening was introduced by Mikhail Botvinnink in 1945. The game typically continues 6...dxc4 7.e4 (note: 7.a4 to prevent Black's b5 does not work) The Botvinnik Variation was invented by Klaus Junge, but he was not the first person known to have played it. Black makes the thematic pawn capture 5...dxc4 immediately. White will fianchetto his king bishop and castle kingside, while Black will play ...c5, ...Qb6, castle queenside. More than 90% of games continue with 5.Bg5 or 5.e3, but there are some sidelines that are worth a quick look. The move 5.Qb3 is an alternative way of protecting the c-pawn. If Black plays 5...dxc4 instead, White will recapture with 6.Qxc4. David Vigorito, Play the Semi-Slav, Quality Chess, 2008 ISBN 978-91-85779-01-7Authority control databases InternationalFASTNationalSpainGermanyIsraelUnited StatesRetr.  pawn. chess.
D41: The Queen's Gambit Declined is a chess opening in which Black declines a pawn offered by White. The Orthodox Line can be reached by a number of different move orders, such as 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 d5. 3...Bb4 (the Accelerated Ragozin) intends to transpose to the Semi-Slav after 4...Nf6. 3...a6 (the Janowski Variation) threatens ...dxc4 followed by ...b5, attempting to hold on to the pawn. The Three Knights Variation of the Queen's Gambit Declined is usually reached from the move order 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 d5 4.Nc3, played to avoid the Nimzo-Indian Defense (from the white point of view) and the Exchange Variation. The Vienna Variation occurs after Black plays 4...dxc4. The Semi-Slav Defense occurs after black plays 4...c6 in the Three Knights Variation. Placing the bishop on Bg5 allows Black to exchange more freely with moves like Nf6-e4. Peter Leko, usually an e4 player, used this variation as White to beat Vladimir Kramnik in their 2004 World Championship Match.
B17: Classical Variation: 1.e4 c6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Bf5 5. Ng3 Bg6 6. h4 h6 7. Nf3 Nd7 8. h5 Bh7 9. Bd3 Bxd3 10.Qxd3. Although White's pawn on h5 looks ready to attack, it can prove a weakness in an endgame. Viktor Korchnoi played 5...exf6 many times (including his first world championship match with Anatoly Karpov), and this line has also been employed by Ulf Andersson. The 3...Bf5 variation that follows 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 g6 has gained popularity after having been widely regarded as inferior for many years. The Panov–Botvinnik Attack begins with the move 4.c4. The Fantasy Variation aims to exploit White's weaknesses on the a7–g1 diagonal. The Two Knights Variation was played by Bobby Fischer in his youth, but has since declined in popularity. After the moves 1.e4 c6 2.Nc3 d5 3.Qf3!? (Goldman Variation), White's position is sound according to Graham Burgess. The percentage white wins, black wins or a draw occurs in the games of highly rated players (2200+ FIDE) in four lines of the Caro–Kann Defence. Other lines are ineffective or doubtful.

B10: The Caro-Kann Defense is known above all for its solidity. The defining move, 1...c6, is the fourth most popular reply to 1.e4. Black almost always captures with 3...dxe4, with White making the obvious reply 4...Nxe4. The Caro-Kann is named for Horatio Caro and Marcus Kann, two 19th century players. At the 1927 New York tournament, world champion Jose Raul Capablanca used it as his main weapon against 1.e4. In his 1958 rematch with GM Vassily Smyslov, GM Mikhail Botvinnik became the first player to use it in a match for the world championship. The Caro–Kann has a reputation of being solid but somewhat boring. Black makes very few compromises in pawn structure and plays a timely ...c6–c5 to contest the d4-square. More popular recently are variations with Black castling kingside and even leaving his king in the centre. These variations can be sharp and dynamic. Viktor Korchnoi played 5...exf6 many times (including his first world championship match with Anatoly Karpov), and this line has also been employed by Ulf Andersson. The Gurgenidze Variation is 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 g6. The Advance Variation has since been revitalized by aggressive lines such as the Bayonet Attack. The Panov–Botvinnik Attack begins with the move 4.c4. The Fantasy Variation, formerly known as the Tartakower or Maroçzy variation, 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.f3, somewhat resembles the Blackmar–Diemer Gambit. Black's logical and probably best reply is 3...Bg4. Karpov/Steinitz Variation: 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 dxe4 4.Nxe4 Nf6 5.Nxf6+ exf6 6.Bc4Milner–Barry Gambit, Rasa-Studier Gambit:1.e3 c3 2. d3 3. Nc3 4. Nxe4 5. Bf5 6.h4 h6 7.Nf3 Nd7 8.h5 Bh5 9.Bxd3 10.Qe2 Nb6.

More than 90% of games continue with 5.Bg5 or 5.e3, but there are some sidelines that are worth a quick look. The move 5.Qb3 is an alternative way of protecting the c-pawn. If Black plays 5...dxc4 instead, White will recapture with 6.Qxc4. David Vigorito, Play the Semi-Slav, Quality Chess, 2008 ISBN 978-91-85779-01-7Authority control databases InternationalFASTNationalSpainGermanyIsraelUnited StatesRetr.  pawn. chess.
B87: The Sicilian Defence is a chess opening that begins with the following moves:1.e4 c5ECOB20–B99OriginGiulio Cesare Polerio, 1594Named afterSicilyParentKing's Pawn Game. Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov are two of the most famous players to have played the Sicilian. The Sicilian is the most played and most analysed opening at both the club and master levels. It fell out of favour when some of the world's leading players rejected it. The most frequent continuation is 3...Nf6 4.Be2, when 4...Nxe4? loses to 5.Qa4+ and likewise 4 ...Nc4?: loses to 6 d5 and 7a4+. 2.d3 signals White's intention to develop along King's Indian Attack lines, and usually transposes to the Closed Sicilian. White often supports the e5-pawn with 3.f4 or 3.Nf3. The drawback of 2.e5 is that no additional pressure is brought to the centre. The Sicilian Defence has more codes than any other opening. The Wing Gambit is generally considered too reckless, and rarely seen in grandmaster praxis. GM Joe Gallagher calls it "a forgotten relic, hardly having set foot in a tournament hall since ... well, not a lot"  c3 Sicilian is popular. Players usually enter the Grand Prix Attack by playing 2Nc4 before 3f3 or 3f4.
D25: The Queen's Gambit Accepted is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 d52. c4 dxc4. It is the third most popular option on Black's second move, after 2...e6 and 2...c6 (the Slav Defense) Black usually allows the pawn to be recaptured and uses the time expended to play against White's centre. 3.e4 is an old move that became popular again in the 1990s. The Alekhine Variation focuses on rapid development of pieces along with domination of the centre. 3.e3 prepares immediate recovery of the pawn and has often been employed by strong players, including Anatoly Karpov. 3. Nc3 was recommended by Keene and Jacobs in their opening repertoire for White. The queen check by 3.Qa4+ Nc6 4.Nf3 will quickly regain the pawn with Qxc4. 3...e5, 3...Nf6, and 3...a6 are all reasonable replies.

B80: The Sicilian Defence was analysed by Giulio Polerio in his 1594 manuscript on chess. It is used by world champions Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov. Black's most common move after 2.Nf3 is ...Nf6, followed by 2...e6. The immediate 5...e5?! is met by 6.Bb5+!, when Black must either play 6...Bd7 or 6...Nbd7. White's idea is to play f3, Qd2, 0-0-0 and g4 in some order. Black has three main moves: 4...Nc6 (the Taimanov Variation), 4...a6 ( the Kan Variation) and 4...E5. Black sometimes plays 3...e4 to avoid both moves; then 4...Bc4 is considered best. 2...Nc6 is the most common choice, but 2...e6 and 2...d6 are often played. Main line of the Closed Sicilian is 2.Nc3 Nc6 3.g3 g6 4.Bg2 Bg7 5.d3 d6 (diagram) Black's best reply is 2...exd5 3.5! Nf6!, the Talbit Gambit, which has caused 2f4 to decline in popularity. White can play the positional 5.Bb5, threatening to double Black's pawns. The modern main line runs 2. nc2 Nc2 3. f4 g4 4.f4 g6 5.Nf3 Bg3.
B89: The Sicilian Defence is a chess opening that begins with the following moves:1.e4 c5ECOB20–B99OriginGiulio Cesare Polerio, 1594Named afterSicilyParentKing's Pawn Game. The Wing Gambit is generally considered too reckless, and rarely seen in grandmaster praxis. GM Joe Gallagher calls it "a forgotten relic, hardly having set foot in a tournament hall since ... well, not a lot"  c3 Sicilian is popular. Players usually enter the Grand Prix Attack by playing 2Nc4 before 3f3 or 3f4.
D14: The Slav Defense is one of the primary defenses to the Queen's Gambit. It was analyzed as early as 1590, but not explored extensively until the 1920s. Many masters of Slavic descent helped develop the theory of this opening, including Alapin, Alekhine and Bogoljubov. After 3...Nf6, the main line is 4.Nc3. Black can try the Winawer Countergambit, 3...e5, which was introduced in Marshall–Winawer, Monte Carlo 1901 but this is thought to be slightly better for White. White can also try the following alternatives:4.Qc2 or 4.Qb3. Another way to play is 4...Bg4. White's sharpest try against 4...dxc4 is the Slav Geller Gambit, 5.e4. With 5.a4, White acts against ...b5 and prepares 6.e 4 and 7.Bxc4. Black's main move is 5...Bf5.
